Award.AbstractNarration: Arizona State University is exploring the role of visual representations in student learning in undergraduate geology courses. This study investigates how students interact with, and learn from, three different types of representations: textbook figures, 3D virtual environments, and annotated sketches of geologic systems. The first part of the research involves how students interact with figures in introductory geology textbooks, focusing on how the interaction varies for different types of figures, for the degree of integration of figures and text, and for differences in the background and abilities of the student. A second component investigates student interactions with 2D and 3D virtual environments, such as static portrayals of 3D terrains on maps, various types of interactive animations, and immersive 3D environments, such as the GeoWall. A third component explores the role of annotated sketches (concept sketches) in geoscience learning and teaching, especially the use of sketches as a conceptual bridge between the other two types of visual representations and a deeper understanding of geoscience concepts and processes. The results from this research is expected to help instructors examine the role of visual representations in geoscience learning and develop strategies for more effective geoscience teaching. The project team is developing exemplary curricular materials that explicitly help students and instructors implement these strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes



The goal of this project was to investigate and better understand how college students interact with the type of educational materials typically encountered in an introductory geoscience class, with an ultimate aim to increase learning by improving curricular materials and teaching approaches. We used eye-tracking technology, the first use of such technology in the geosciences, to track how students observed landscape photographs, 2D and 3D representations of geologic features, and material that had both text and figures. We documented that many students examine only the center of the image and are greatly distracted by humans, animals, and other non-pertinent objects in photographs, and this limits how much of the scene they examine and caused them to not concentrate on key landscape features. Signaling, through overlays and callouts on top of the photograph, helps guide student attention to the key features and improves student learning.

 

We also investigated how the arrangement of text and associated figures influences the strategies and behaviors of students when they study textbook-style material. We compared three different figure-text arrangements, and documented that the traditional layout of textbooks resulted in the least student learning, while textbook-type materials that featured integration of text and figures resulted in more learning. A key determinant on learning was how often a student went back and forth from text to figures. We further showed that having students do a concept sketch improved how much they learned later, on an unrelated topic presented as integrated text and figures.

 

Our project provides clear guidance into how textbooks and other curricular material should be structured and what objects should and should not be included in photographs and illustrations. Our research preceding and occurring during this project resulted in the creation of a new type of textbook, one that lacks large blocks of text but instead is designed around short text blocks integrated tightly with figures. The first textbook using this
approach, Exploring Geology, has received an award for its innovative design and has been very successful in colleges and universities across the country. It has spawned similar textbooks in the geosciences and in other fields, including accounting, nursing, and geography. With such materials, students can learn content on their own, freeing up instructors to concentrate on teaching student to think broadly, reason critically, and solve important problems.
